attributes.title: A Multidisciplinary Approach to Decreasing Length of Stay in Acute Care Surgery Patients

q1.value: A Multidisciplinary Approach to Decreasing Length of Stay in Acute Care Surgery Patients

q2.value: Christopher D. DEPESA, RN, MS, Majed El Hechi, Rachael MCKENZIE, RN, MSN, CCM, Karen WAAK PT, DPT, CCS, Leslie MCLAUGHLIN, MS, OTR/L, Yuchiao CHANG, PhD, Alice GERVASINI, PhD, RN, NE-C, George C. VELMAHOS, MD, PhD, MEd, Haytham M.A. KAAFARANI, MD, MPH

q3.value:
Hospital length of stay (LOS) has been proposed as a key indicator of appropriate resource utilization in the American healthcare system.  Prolonged LOS is associated with poor clinical outcomes and increased cost to patients, healthcare facilities, and state and federal governments. Thus, healthcare providers have a responsibility to effectively and efficiently address a patient’s discharge needs by deploying appropriate but not unnecessary resources.

The acute care surgery (ACS) patient population, which includes those presenting emergently after a traumatic event or surgical emergency, has unique characteristics that make their discharge from the hospital challenging.  These characteristics often include: complex injury patterns necessitating extensive rehabilitation, inconsistent insurance coverage, and home addresses in states other than the treating hospital. These factors all impact the providers’ ability to match the patient with an appropriate discharge destination. Interestingly, it has been demonstrated that the root cause of prolonged LOS in the trauma patient is often not related to the severity of the injury or clinical needs, but to system-related issues.  Because prolonged LOS in this patient population is so often closely associated with statewide rather than hospital-specific system-related factors, it has been debated whether LOS should be used as a measure of quality.  However, hospitals acknowledge that a prolonged LOS adversely impacts their performance both clinically and financially, and thus decreasing LOS became a de facto priority for many institutions.

q4.value: In this study, we sought to: 1) design and implement a multidisciplinary quality improvement (QI) initiative for LOS reduction; 2) measure the impact of our QI initiative; and 3) synthesize the lessons we learned from our efforts.  We hypothesized that a multidisciplinary approach to address barriers to discharge early in the hospitalization period would lead to a reduction in the LOS of ACS patients.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The project was a quality improvement with an observational pre-post design at an urban, academic. A period of two years before the intervention was compared to the period of two years after the intervention.

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

question.value:
Using Tableau software, we created an interactive database and dashboard of our ACS patients that can be updated in real-time. The database was comprised of multiple variables (e.g. age, comorbidities, admit/discharge date/diagnosis/destination), including the UHC benchmarked eLOS, which could be utilized to identify the causes of prolonged O/E LOS.  The data dashboard allowed concurrent monitoring of the initiative’s status and progress.
The pre-QI period was compared to the post-QI period.  The primary outcome, O/E LOS ratios, were generated and compared across two time periods. At the end of the two-year period after the intervention, the multidisciplinary group met and reviewed the data to determine what lessons could be learned from the effort.

q13.value: No power analysis was performed for this observational study, The period of two years after the intervention were compared to the two years prior to the intervention.

question.value:
- Admission location: "Intensive Care unit ICU", Floor, Other floors
- Hospital Observed Length of stay, Expected Lengths of Stay
- Discharge destination: "Home",” “Home with Services,” “Skilled Nursing Facility (SNF),” “Rehabilitation,” and “Long Term Acute Care (LTAC)”. 
- Free text examples of interventions to decrease Length of Stay identified during  study period.

Analysis was done on all ACS patients, stratified by discharge units (Surgical Floor, Surgical ICU, or Other) and by discharge status (Home, Home with Services, SNF, Rehab, and LTAC). The eLOS, oLOS, and the O/E ratio were compared using the Wilcoxon signed-rank test.  All analysis was done using SAS version 9.4.  Statistical significance is defined as two-sided p < 0.05.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Perceptions of Change in Public Opinion

analyses.value:
We will fit a linear mixed effects model with a fixed effect of the actual amount of change for each rating and a random effect of participant and item. The outcome will be the estimated amount of change. Our result of interest in this model is the intercept, which we predict will be positive and significant (meaning that participants estimate, overall, more change than there was actual change).

Each item will be also be tested with a two-tailed one-sample t-test. The mu value for each t-test will be the actual amount of change observed in empirical data (collected from Gallup, ANES, GSS, etc.). 

We will then sort the results of each of these 51 tests into four categories: overestimation, underestimation, wrong direction, and correct. Overestimation means that estimated and actual change have the same sign and estimated change is significantly greater than actual change OR that there was no significant actual change (difference is within survey’s margin of error) but participants significantly estimated change in either direction. Underestimation means that estimated and actual change have the same sign and estimated change is significantly less than actual change. Wrong direction means that estimated and actual change are significantly different from each other and have opposite signs. Correct means that actual and estimated change do not significantly differ. We predict that a plurality of items will be overestimated, and that a majority of items will be overestimated or estimated in the wrong direction.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded only if they fail one or more attention checks.

dependent.value: The dependent variable is estimated change in public opinions. This will be measured by asking participants to estimate the percentage of Americans who answered in a certain way on a public opinion question in two different years. Estimated change = estimate for later year - estimate for earlier year. Actual change = actual opinion in later year - actual opinion in earlier year.

conditions.value: All participants will be assigned to the same condition. Participants will complete a semi-random subset of 20 items out of 51 possible items. The sample is semi-random because eight of the items require extra instructions, so participants will either get the whole block of those eight or none.

hypothesis.value: Do people know how public opinion has changed over time?

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: Perceptions of Change in Public Opinion

registration_responses.hypothesis: Do people know how public opinion has changed over time?

q1.value: The Effect of Generic phrases on News Headline Engagement and Believability

q3.value: This study will examine whether news headlines that include a generic phrases (e.g., "Scientists say bees can do basic math")  are more or less engaging and believable than than their quantified equivelants (e.g., "Some scientists say bees can do basic math")

q4.value:
Directional hypotheses 
Generic headlines imply greater scientific consensus than quantified headlines
Generic headlines are more relevant than quantified headlines
Generic headlines are more engaging than quantified headlines 

Non-directional hypothesis 
The mean believability rating for generic headilines is not equal to the mean believability rating of quantified headilines

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
One factor latin squared repeated measures design.  The IV is headline type and has two levels (generic vs quantified).  There will be 24 target headlines (two versions of each) 

The DVs are listed below under 'measured variables'

q9.value: Particpants will be randomly assigned by Qualtrics to one of two latin squared lists (each list containing 24 target headlines plus 8 fillers). Each partcipant will see the headlines in a different random order.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited via Prolific.co; an online research platform where participants are paid in return for the time taken to complete surveys (we have funding to pay £6.00 per hour pro rata).   Prescreening will ensure that  the study is only advertised to those who are aged ≥ 18 years old, are fluent in English and have not taken part studies directly related to this one.  Participants will take part on a first-come first-served basis.

q13.value: We will recruit a 185 participants via prolific.co

q14.value:
Power analysis was conducted assuming a counterbalanced (latin squared) repeated measures design with one fixed factor  (with two levels) and two random factors (participants and items). Power analysis was conducted using the two random factor Power calculator associated with the Annual Review of Psychology paper by Judd, Westfall and Kenny (2016).  https://jakewestfall.shinyapps.io/two_factor_power/ 

We have sufficient funds to recruit 185 particpants. With an anticipated effect size of d=0.5 and 24 target items this sample  would achieve power of 0.936.     If the effect size were d=0.4  the level of power would still be adequate at 0.796


 Judd, C. M., Westfall, J., & Kenny, D. A. (2016). Experiments with more than one random factor: Designs, analytic models, and statistical power. Annual Review of Psychology.

q15.value: We will request exactly 185 participants from Prolific.  Sometimes the number completing the study is slightly  higher than requested (e.g.,  if a participant completes the study but fails to click the reward link at the end, then an additional participant will be recruited)

question.value:
The IV is Headline type (generic vs quantified). There will be two versions of each headline. See example below 

Scientists say bees can do basic math  [Generic]
Some scientists say bees can do basic math [Quantified]

There will be 24 headline pairs.

The following variables will be measured for each headline (all using sliding scales) 

1.	Perceived degree of scientific consensus implied by headline "“Please estimate how many relevant experts you think this headline applies to" (0-100 scale)
2.	Headline believability “This headline is believable”  (1-7 scale)
3.	Positive cognitive effects of the headline (relevance)  “This headline increased my knowledge” (1-7 scale)
4.	Ease of processing the headline (relevance)  “This headline is easy to understand”
5.	Likelihood of private engagement with the headline  “I would be likely to read an article with this headline”  (1-7 scale)
6.	Likelihood of public engagement with the headline  “I would be likely to publicly engage with this headline if I saw it posted on social media (e.g.,  Like, Share, Comment on etc.)” (1-7 scale)
7.	Prior beliefs relating to the headline “Prior to reading the headline, did you have any pre-existing beliefs on the claim made by the headline?”  (1-4 scale)

Each DV will be analysed by running a generalised linear mixed model  (using the lme4  package in R).  Participants and Items will be treated as random factors. The fixed factor will be Headline type (I.e., Generic vs Quantified)

q21.value: p<0.05 (one tailed tests for directional hypotheses, two tailed for non-directional)

q22.value:
Prescreening: 

Prolific will not advertise the study to members of the particpant pool if: 

1) They are aged under 18 years (ethical approval is granted to test those 18 or above)
2) They do not speak English as their first language 
3) They have taken part in related studies 

Exclusion: 
Participants will be excluded from the analysis if:

1) They do not finish the survey (according to our ethical approval, participants who do not finish the survey are considered to have withdrawn)
2) They decalare that they have not completed the survey seriously. Following Aust et al. (2013) the final question will explicitly ask participants if they completed the survey seriously. 
3) They contact the researcher to withdraw consent (quoting their randomly generated ID number)

q23.value: All questions will be set to 'Force Response' so there should be no missing data among those who complete the survey. If a participant has completed the survey but has missing data, it will be assumed there has been a technical issue with that participant and they will be excluded from the analysis.

q24.value: We are measuring prior beliefs about each headline so we can report it as a descriptive statistic (we deliberately chose headlines people would be unlikely to hold strong prior beliefs about, so this measure is simply to confirm that), but we may  explore the effect of prior beliefs on headline believability and engagement in exploritory analysis or as a covariate.

q25.value: This is one of a series of studies funded by a Leverhulme Trust Research Project Grant awarded to Matthew Haigh (RPJ-2019-158). Each study will be pre-registered seperately.

attributes.title: PSYC 3301 - Research Preregistration: Smiling vs Neutral Face and Interpersonal Attraction
Causes and treatment of Idiopathic Systemic Capillary Leak Syndrome (Clarkson’s disease): a scoping review.
attributes.description: Scoping review exploring the body of evidence about the causes, acute treatment and prophylaxis of Idiopathic Systemic Capillary Leak Syndrome.

q1.value: Causes and treatment of Idiopathic Systemic Capillary Leak Syndrome (Clarkson’s disease): a scoping review.

q3.value:
Idiopathic systemic capillary leak syndrome (ISCLS), also known as Clarkson’s disease from the first description in 1960 [1], is characterized by episodes of sudden generalized endothelial hyperpermeability leading to distributive shock [2]. Although ISCLS is a rare disease, with about 300 cases described in the last fifty years [3], it is a relevant challenge for critical care physician during the acute phases, because it is usually unrecognized at onset and often is misdiagnosed as septic shock or polycythemia vera. The traditional approach to the common causes of shock with a high volume of fluids and catecholamines’ infusion, attempting to restore a near-normal blood pressure, further worsen the illness severity by inducing iatrogenic complications. The evidence about the ISCLS etiology, treatment of the acute phase, and the effect of prophylaxis is weak and mostly derived by case series reports, case reports, and expert's opinion.
The treatment of acute (shock) phase was traditionally based on fluid resuscitation and catecholamines administration in the attempt to restore an adequate blood pressure. Some authors suggest that this approach is harmful because seems to carry iatrogenic complications. Furthermore, several prophylactic regimens were attempted. The intravenous administration of immunoglobulin G at monthly intervals has been suggested to reduce frequency and severity of the ISCLS flares.

q4.value: To review diagnostic criteria, the prophylactic regimens, and acute treatments of ISCLS.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Scoping review.
The authors will search Medline, Pubmed, Embase, CINHAL, and Scopus databases for the terms “systemic capillary leak syndrome”

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The principal investigators independently will search the Medline, Pubmed, Embase, CINHAL, and Scopus databases for the terms “systemic capillary leak syndrome”. The abstracts will be analyzed, and only articles describing the idiopathic form of the systemic capillary leak syndrome will be considered. Moreover, the references of the articles included in the analysis will be examined, and relevant articles will be then included. Articles in English, German, French, Spanish, and Italian language will be included.
The studies will be excluded from the review if the episodic edema was secondary to malignancies, chemotherapy, engraftment syndrome, differentiation syndrome, ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome, hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis, hemorrhagic fever, ebola virus disease, extracorporeal life support for cardiogenic shock or cardiac arrest.

q13.value: The sample size cannot be pre-specified due to the design of scoping review

question.value:
1) Diagnostic criteria (edema, shock, hemoconcentration Htc>50%, hypoalbuminemia <30g/L, monoclonal gammopathy)
2) clinical course in children and adults
3) treatment of shock phases
4) prophylactic regimens
5) hypothesized causes
summary of findings in table synthesis

registration_responses.q1: Causes and treatment of Idiopathic Systemic Capillary Leak Syndrome (Clarkson’s disease): a scoping review.
registration_responses.q3:
Idiopathic systemic capillary leak syndrome (ISCLS), also known as Clarkson’s disease from the first description in 1960 [1], is characterized by episodes of sudden generalized endothelial hyperpermeability leading to distributive shock [2]. Although ISCLS is a rare disease, with about 300 cases described in the last fifty years [3], it is a relevant challenge for critical care physician during the acute phases, because it is usually unrecognized at onset and often is misdiagnosed as septic shock or polycythemia vera. The traditional approach to the common causes of shock with a high volume of fluids and catecholamines’ infusion, attempting to restore a near-normal blood pressure, further worsen the illness severity by inducing iatrogenic complications. The evidence about the ISCLS etiology, treatment of the acute phase, and the effect of prophylaxis is weak and mostly derived by case series reports, case reports, and expert's opinion.
The treatment of acute (shock) phase was traditionally based on fluid resuscitation and catecholamines administration in the attempt to restore an adequate blood pressure. Some authors suggest that this approach is harmful because seems to carry iatrogenic complications. Furthermore, several prophylactic regimens were attempted. The intravenous administration of immunoglobulin G at monthly intervals has been suggested to reduce frequency and severity of the ISCLS flares.
registration_responses.q4: To review diagnostic criteria, the prophylactic regimens, and acute treatments of ISCLS.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

Moreover, the references of the articles included in the analysis will be examined, and relevant articles will be then included. Articles in English, German, French, Spanish, and Italian language will be included.
The studies will be excluded from the review if the episodic edema was secondary to malignancies, chemotherapy, engraftment syndrome, differentiation syndrome, ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome, hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis, hemorrhagic fever, ebola virus disease, extracorporeal life support for cardiogenic shock or cardiac arrest.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Syntactic Satiation and Adaptation to Speaker Identity: Part 1. Replication of Snyder (2000)

sample.value: A total of 180 participants will be recruited (60 participants per survey list). Each participant will see 1 of the 3 survey lists (a Latin Square design), with each list containing 60 trials (45 test items and 15 filler items).

analyses.value: We will use a linear mixed effects model predicting acceptability ratings from fixed effects of presentation order, condition, and their interaction. Random by-participant and by-item intercepts will be included, as well as by-participant and by-item slopes for the fixed effects. Syntactic satiation will be detected as a positive main effect of presentation order, or interactions between presentation order and condition.

dependent.value: Participants will be asked to rate how "acceptable" each target sentence sound, and give their ratings by dragging a continuous slider. The left end of the scale is marked by "totally unacceptable", and the right end of the scale is marked by "totally acceptable". The position of the slider on the scale will be recorded as the acceptability judgment score (left end is 0, right end is 1, and everywhere else on the scale being evenly spread between 0 and 1).

conditions.value: There are three test conditions in total: subject-island violation, Complex-NP violation, and whether-island violation. Each participant will see a survey containing all three conditions (15 of each), and 15 grammatical filler items. There are 4 ungrammatical control items interspersed in each survey.

hypothesis.value: Snyder (2000) observed that certain island violating constructions "satiate" ( exhibit increase in acceptability) when participants are exposed to a certain number of them. In this study we are trying to replicate part of the findings by Snyder (2000). Specifically, we are testing if subject-island violation, Complex-NP violation, and whether-island violation exhibit satiation effect.

summary.value:
1. Review title.

Anti-vascular endothelial growth factor agents for choroidal neovascularization secondary to pseudoxanthoma elasticum: A systematic review and meta-analysis.


2. Anticipated or actual start date.

February 3th 2020.

3. Anticipated completion date.

November 1st, 2020

4. Stage of review at time of this submission. 

Preliminary Searches.

5. Named contact.

Adrian Bailey

6. Named contact email

abail082@uottawa.ca

7. Named contact address

The Ottawa Hospital

501 Smyth Road, Ottawa, Ontario.

8. Named contact phone number.

6138585029

9. Organisational affiliation of the review.

University of Ottawa

The Ottawa Hospital

10. Review team members and their organisational affiliations.

Mr. Adrian Bailey

Dr. Adrian Tsang

Dr. Michael Dollin

*All are associated with the University of Ottawa and The Ottawa Hospital.

11. Funding sources/sponsors.

None.

12. Conflicts of interest.

None.

13. Collaborators.

None.

14. Review question.

Do anti-vascular endothelial growth factor agents improve functional and structural outcomes of patients with choroidal neovascularization secondary to pseudoxanthoma elasticum compared to conventional treatment?

15. Searches.

Pubmed, Scopus, and Clinical Trials.gov on Februrary 20th 2020. English language articles only. Unpublished studies will try to be located and included to the best of our abilities.

16. URL to search strategy.

Search strategy for PubMed: choroidal neovascularization pseudoxanthoma elasticum.

("choroidal neovascularisation"[All Fields] OR "choroidal neovascularization"[MeSH Terms] OR ("choroidal"[All Fields] AND "neovascularization"[All Fields]) OR "choroidal neovascularization"[All Fields]) AND ("pseudoxanthoma elasticum"[MeSH Terms] OR ("pseudoxanthoma"[All Fields] AND "elasticum"[All Fields]) OR "pseudoxanthoma elasticum"[All Fields])

Search Strategy for Scopus: choroidal neovascularization pseudoxanthoma elasticum

TITLE-ABS-KEY ( choroidal AND neovascularization AND pseudoxanthoma AND elasticum )

ClinicalTrials.gov: pseudoxanthoma elasticum 

17. Condition or domain being studied.

Pseudoxanthoma elasticum (PXE) is a rare, autosomal recessive, and multi-system disease due to ABCC6 gene mutations that affects the eye. In the later stages of the disease, macular atrophy and retinal hemorrhages may develop, leading to irreversible loss of central vision. Vision impairment has been found to most severely affect the quality of life of patients with PXE, exceeding that of cardiovascular related complications. The treatment of CNV secondary to PXE has been centred around the limiting the progression of retinal hemorrhages due to CNV. In particular, the use of intravitreal anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) agents has been shown to stabilize and improve the best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) and central retinal thickness (CRT). In addition, good evidence exists for the use of bevacizumab and ranibizumab for angioid streaks. However, to date and to our knowledge, the literature lacks a systematic review and meta-analysis of the effectiveness of anti-VEGF therapy for the treatment of CNV secondary to PXE.

Therefore, the objective of this review is to provide an overview and evaluate the current evidence on the effectiveness of anti-VEGF therapy on the functional and structural outcomes in the context of CNV secondary to PXE.

Outcomes: Best Corrected Visual Acuity (BCVA), Central Retinal Thickness (CRT), Central Macular Thickness (CMT), greatest lesion height, and quality of life scores.

18. Participants/population.

Inclusion: Patients with choroidal neovascularization secondary to pseudoxanthoma elasticum.
Exclusion: Patients under 18 years of age. Patients with choroidal neovascularization secondary to another condition. Patients receiving combination therapy (i.e., agents and/or treatments in addition to anti-Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor (VEGF))

19. Intervention(s), exposure(s).

Anti-VEGF agents (ranibizumab, bevacizumab, aflibercept) administered through intravitreal injection to affected eye. 

20. Comparator(s)/control.

Studies will be separated according to comparator used:

1)	Patient BCVA, CRT, CMT, greatest lesion height, and quality of life scores at baseline.
2)	Patient BCVA, CRT, CMT, greatest lesion height in contralateral, untreated eye.

21. Types of study to be included.

The studies are required to be comparative. Eligible study designs include retrospective cohort, prospective cohort, randomized controlled trials (RCT), and quasi-randomized clinical trials. Case reports, case series, and other studies reporting less than 4 patients will be excluded from the quantitative analysis, but will be informally included in the qualitative part of the review.

22. Context.

Studies in hospital providing anti-VEGF therapy to patients with choroidal neovascularization secondary to pseudoxanthoma elasticum.

23. Main outcome(s).

Primary outcomes: Patient BCVA, CRT, CMT, and greatest lesion height.


24. Additional outcome(s).

Quality of life scores

25. Data extraction (selection and coding).

Study selection
•	Two independent, blinded reviewers will apply the inclusion and exclusion criteria to select studies for inclusion into the systematic review. Discrepancies will be resolved by a third reviewer, the supervisor of the study.
•	Excel software will be used to record decisions. 

Data extraction
•	Information about and not limited to study design and methodology, participant demographics and baseline characteristics, and adverse events will be recorded. Study authors will be contacted for additional information if required.
•	Two independent, blinded reviewers will extract data from select studies. Less than 5% error between reviewers will be acceptable in cases where estimation is required (i.e., using ImageJ software to estimate values from Figures when the data is not reported in text or supplemental materials). Discrepancies will be resolved by a third reviewer, the supervisor of the study.
•	Excel software will be used to record data. 

26. Risk of bias (quality) assessment.

Methods for assessing risk of bias reported in systematic review protocols should include:
•	The Cochrane risk of bias tool for randomised trials, version 2.0, will be used to assess the risk of bias of all included studies. 
•	Two independent, blinded reviewers will apply the Cochrane risk of bias tool for randomised trials, version 2.0, to assess the risk of bias and quality of studies. Discrepancies will be resolved by a third reviewer, the supervisor of the study.
•	Assessment will be done at the study level.
•	Only studies will a low risk of bias will be included in the meta-analysis of outcomes. 

28. Strategy for data synthesis.

•	Data will only be synthesized if there are more than two studies that report on the same outcome. 
•	Outcomes that will be synthesized include BCVA, CRT, CMT, greatest lesion height, and quality of life scores.
•	The mean difference in a random-effects meta-analysis for quantitative data will be used to pool data for BCVA, CRT, CMT, and greatest lesion height, as these outcomes should be directly comparable. The standardised mean difference will be used for quality of life scores.

29. Analysis of subgroups or subsets.

Subgroup analysis is not planned. 

30. Type and method of review.

Systematic Review and Meta Analysis

31. Language.

English

32. Country.

Canada

33. Dissemination plans.

Publication to academic journal.

34. Keywords.

Systematic review; meta-analysis; Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor;  pseudoxanthoma elasticum; choroidal neovascularization; secondary; ranibizumab; bevacizumab; aflibercept; intravitreal; injection.

35. Current review status.

Ongoing.

attributes.title: Vicarious Dissonance in a French Context: Reacting to the Inconsistency of Others
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value:
IV1: Vicarious dissonance (presence versus absence), between-subject factor.
IV2: Measures of attitudes towards increasing tuition fees (Time 1 and Time 2), within-subject factor (repeated measure)

question2b.value:
The dependent variable will be the change in attitudes towards increasing tuition fees, measured in two steps: step 1 (i.e., pre-manipulation measurement, before the vicarious dissonance procedure) and step 2 (i.e., post-manipulation measurement, after the vicarious dissonance procedure). This scale, translated from Stalder & Baron (1998), consists of 4 items: 
"The university should raise tuition yearly by a moderate amount" (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree), "How would you describe your overall attitude toward raising tuition?" (1 = extremely unfavorable, 7 = extremely favorable), "To what extent do you think there are advantages to never raising tuition?" (1 = no advantages, 7 = a great many; reverse scored), and "To what extent do you think that a modest yearly increase in tuition is a good general strategy in maintaining the quality of university education?" (1 = not at all, 7 = a great deal).

These pre- and post-manipulation intra-individual measures of behavioral intentions will allow us to measure and analyze the magnitude of change in behavioral intention, more specifically, the magnitude of reduction in dissonance (Martinie et al 2013).

question3b.value:
We will measure the proximity with the group as a covariate (measured in the pre-manipulation questionnaire). Our measure of proximity with the group consists of 4 measures: group prototypicality, social identification with the group, similarity and interpersonal proximity to the group. 
1. The measure of prototypicality was based on the study by Hogg, Cooper-Shaw, & Holzworth (1993). Participants were asked to identify the characteristics of the group of youth (18 to 25 years of age) and to describe a prototype in no more five lines. They will then be asked to indicate how difficult it was for them to generate this description (1 = very easy, 7 = very difficult), how confident they were that this was an accurate description (1 = not very convinced, 7 = very convinced), and what percentage of the group they think generally agrees with their description. Finally, the prototypicality of the participants will be measured in 1 item: "How typical of the group of young people do you consider yourself to? "(1 = not at all representative, 7 = very representative), adapted in French from studies by Hogg, Cooper-Shaw, and Holzworth (1993). 
2. Social identification with the participant's group will be measured in 1 item, "I strongly identify with the youth group" (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree) (Reysen, Katzarska-Miller, Nesbit, & Pierce, 2013). 
3. The IOS scale (Aron, Aron, & Smollan, 1992) will measure interpersonal closeness to the group, and 
4. similarity to the group will be measured in 4 items, "How do you feel similar to the person in general", "...in terms of personal dispositions", "...in terms of attitudes", and "...in terms of background," (1 = not at all similar, 7 = very similar), adapted in French from the studies of Stephan, Liberman, & Trope (2011).

question10b.value:
To participate in this study, students will register on a platform. They will be given a brief presentation of the study, and will be asked to complete a pre-manipulation questionnaire online in order to participate in the study.

Pre-manipulation questionnaire. This questionnaire will include several measures: 
- Attitudes towards increasing tuition fees (Dependent Variable, Time 1)
- Proximity to the group (covariate)
- Demographic information (sex, date of birth, parents' socio-professional category, initials)

1. For the presence of vicarious dissonance condition: 
Participants will be greeted by an experimenter who will tell them that this is a paired study. The experimenter will then stage a telephone conversation with another experimenter during which he or she will learn that the other participant has arrived.

Once the participants are seated in the experiment room, the experimenter will tell them that this is a computer study. The experimenter will explain that he was studying linguistic subcultures, to explore whether the mere fact of living together might cause unique speech patterns to develop (Norton et al., 2003). We stressed these potential differences between groups to make group concerns salient (Turner et al., 1987). The experimenter will specify that in his research, he is particularly interested in the language differences between the youth group (18-25 years old) and the senior group (65-75 years old), and that the paired participant who performs the experiment at the same time as him is also part of the youth group. It will be indicated that this person is of the same sex as him/her: if it is a girl student, we will say that the pair is a girl, if it is a boy, we will say that the pair is a young man (control of group membership). The experimenter will then explain to the participants that in order to study these linguistic subcultures, one of the participants will have to write an argumentative text in favor of increasing tuition fees, while the other will judge this argumentative text on a set of linguistic criteria. To manipulate the negative consequences, the experimenter will explain that the Dean needed students to make speeches in favor of a tuition increase so that the Dean could use the arguments generated to justify any increase. To manipulate the choice of target and the target's opinion of the increasing tuition fees, participants will read a scripted exchange of e-mail messages (via Quaknet software) between the experimenter and the author of the advocacy text. The author of the argumentative text will express his total disagreement with the position to be defended and has asked the experimenter if he is obliged to write it. The experimenter will reply that, of course, he is not obliged to do so, but that he would really appreciate it if they wrote it. The author of the text will answer that he has no more questions and that he was ready to begin. Our cover will be corroborated by the presence of a sheet of paper and a pen on the table in each experimental room. Once instructions have been given, the experimenter will leave the experiment room and the participant will complete the tasks on the computer.
After reading a brief article on linguistic subcultures, all participants will be led to believe that the computer randomly assigns the position of judge or writer of the argumentative text. While waiting for their pair to write the argumentative text, the participants will complete the post-manipulation questionnaire. 

Post-manipulation questionnaire: 
- Attitudes towards increasing tuition fees (Dependent Variable, Time 2)
- Demographic information (sex, date of birth, parents' socio-professional category, initials)
- Manipulation check (perception of observed choice and the negative consequences follow from one’s actions, affiliation with the writer's group)

2. For the absence of vicarious dissonance condition:
Participants will complete only the post-manipulation questionnaire, with dependent measure (i.e., Attitudes towards increasing tuition fees in time 2), without following a vicarious dissonance procedure. 

We will use block randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the two equally sized, predetermined blocks 
For randomization, we will use https://www.random.org/integers/

question4b.value: Participants will be undergraduate student from Aix Marseille University, recruited through advertisements. Participants will be between 18 and 25 years old and will participate in study for experimental credit. Recruitment will take place from February 17 to March 31 at the most, until sufficient participants are recruited for the study.

question5b.value: We will post participant sign-up slots by week on the preceding Friday night, with 85 spots posted per week. We will post new slots each week if, on that Friday night, we are below 100 participants.

question6b.value: Our target sample size is 82 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 100, to provide for participant exclusions. An a-priori power analysis using G*Power 3.1.5 (Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner, & Lang, 2009) showed that 82 participants were necessary to detect a low effect size of .10 at the standard with an α-level of .05 and a power of .80

question7b.value: As soon as we get 82 reliable data.

question9b.value:
We will stop the experiment as soon as a participant asks for it. Moreover, we will provide participants with the opportunity to opt-out the study after completing the experiment.

A manipulation check will also be measured (see Procedure - post-manipulation questionnaire) to ensure that participants have been attentive to the procedure. Any participants who do not have a correct answer to this question will be excluded from the study.

question6c.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the Paired Samples T-Test and Repeated Measures ANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. The post-hoc Tukey-Kramer test adjusts for multiple comparisons.

question7c.value:
As the questionnaires are filled out on computer, the participants are obliged to fill in the requested information in order to continue the experiment. 
Participants who have not completed the pre-manipulation questionnaire prior to the study will not be able to complete the experiment.

question1a.value:
H1. We expect that participants who observe the counter-attitudinal behavior of an ingroup member will experience vicarious dissonance, which they will reduce by changing their attitudes in the direction of the counter-attitudinal act, allowing them to reconcile their beliefs with their observed behaviors.

Specifically, we expect that participants' attitudes towards increasing tuition fees will be more favorable after observing a member of the ingroup act counter-attitudinally (i.e., supporting increasing tuition fees).

question2a.value:
H2. We expect that participants who observe the counter-attitudinal behavior of an ingroup member will experience vicarious dissonance, which they will reduce by changing their attitudes in the direction of the counter-attitudinal act, especially since they are strongly identified with the ingroup.

Specifically, we predict that more highly identified observer will be more favorable their attitudes toward tuition fee increases after observing a member of the ingroup act counter-attitudinally (i.e., supporting increasing tuition fees).

question3a.value: We will use some manipulation check. After the vicarious induced submission procedure (post-experimental questionnaire), to verify the perception of observed choice and the negative consequences follow from one’s actions, the participants will indicate their agreement with the statements: "The writer had the choice to write the argument" and "The writing of this speech may have negative consequences" (7-point scale, ranging from 1 = strongly disagree to 7 = strongly agree). They will then be asked to indicate the affiliation of the writer, specifying whether they were part of the youth group or the senior group.

question1c.value:
Vicarious dissonance: It will be attributed the number “1” for participants in the condition "presence of dissonance", and the number “0” for participants in the condition "absence of dissonance".

Measurement of attitudes towards increasing tuition fees: Participants will indicate on a scale of 1 to 7 their attitudes towards increasing tuition fees, in time 1 and time 2. We will therefore obtain, for each participant, two measures of their attitudes towards increasing tuition fees, pre- and post-manipulation. 

Change in attitudes towards increasing tuition fees. The change in attitudes towards increasing tuition fees will result from the difference obtained between the measure of attitudes towards increasing tuition fees at time 1 and the measure of attitudes towards increasing tuition fees at time 2.

question2c.value: To measure the change in attitudes towards increasing tuition fees as a function of the presence or absence of vicarious dissonance, we will perform a repeated measures ANOVA with the measurement time (time 1 and time 2) as an intra-subject factor (repeated measures) and the vicarious dissonance (presence or absence) as an inter-subject factor.

question3c.value:
IV1: Vicarious dissonance (presence versus absence), inter-subject factor. 

IV2: Measurement of attitudes towards increasing tuition fees (time 1 and time 2), intra-subject factor. 

DV: change in attitudes towards increasing tuition fees.

question1c.value:
Vicarious dissonance: It will be attributed the number “1” for participants in the condition "presence of dissonance", and the number “0” for participants in the condition "absence of dissonance".

Measurement of attitudes towards increasing tuition fees: Participants will indicate on a scale of 1 to 7 their attitudes towards increasing tuition fees, in time 1 and time 2. We will therefore obtain, for each participant, two measures of their attitudes towards increasing tuition fees, pre- and post-manipulation. 

Proximity with the group: We will take the mean of the four questions (self-prototypicality, social identification at the group, similarity and interpersonal closeness with the group) to create a single measure of “proximity with the group”. We will therefore obtain, for each participant, a score of "proximity with the group" on a scale of 1 to 7. 

Change in attitudes towards increasing tuition fees. The change in attitudes towards increasing tuition fees will result from the difference obtained between the measure of attitudes towards increasing tuition fees at time 1 and the measure of attitudes towards increasing tuition fees at time 2.

question2c.value: To measure the change in attitudes towards increasing tuition fees as a function of the presence or absence of vicarious dissonance and as a function of proximity with the group of participant, we will perform a repeated measures ANOVA with the measurement time (time 1 and time 2) as an intra-subject factor (repeated measures), the vicarious dissonance (presence or absence) as an inter-subject factor, and proximity with the group as covariate.

question3c.value:
IV1: Vicarious dissonance (presence versus absence), inter-subject factor. 

IV2: Measurement of attitudes towards increasing tuition fees (time 1 and time 2), intra-subject factor. 

Covariate: proximity with the group.

DV: change in attitudes towards increasing tuition fees.

question4c.value: Vicarious dissonance predicts that only observers highly identified with the group who observe the hypocritical behavior of another ingroup member will experience dissonance vicariously (Cooper & Hogg, 2007).

registration_responses.datacompletion: No, data collection has not begun
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question1a:
H1. We expect that participants who observe the counter-attitudinal behavior of an ingroup member will experience vicarious dissonance, which they will reduce by changing their attitudes in the direction of the counter-attitudinal act, allowing them to reconcile their beliefs with their observed behaviors.

Specifically, we expect that participants' attitudes towards increasing tuition fees will be more favorable after observing a member of the ingroup act counter-attitudinally (i.e., supporting increasing tuition fees).
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question2a:
H2. We expect that participants who observe the counter-attitudinal behavior of an ingroup member will experience vicarious dissonance, which they will reduce by changing their attitudes in the direction of the counter-attitudinal act, especially since they are strongly identified with the ingroup.

Specifically, we predict that more highly identified observer will be more favorable their attitudes toward tuition fee increases after observing a member of the ingroup act counter-attitudinally (i.e., supporting increasing tuition fees).
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question3a: We will use some manipulation check. After the vicarious induced submission procedure (post-experimental questionnaire), to verify the perception of observed choice and the negative consequences follow from one’s actions, the participants will indicate their agreement with the statements: "The writer had the choice to write the argument" and "The writing of this speech may have negative consequences" (7-point scale, ranging from 1 = strongly disagree to 7 = strongly agree). They will then be asked to indicate the affiliation of the writer, specifying whether they were part of the youth group or the senior group.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a:
IV1: Vicarious dissonance (presence versus absence), between-subject factor.
IV2: Measures of attitudes towards increasing tuition fees (Time 1 and Time 2), within-subject factor (repeated measure)
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2b:
The dependent variable will be the change in attitudes towards increasing tuition fees, measured in two steps: step 1 (i.e., pre-manipulation measurement, before the vicarious dissonance procedure) and step 2 (i.e., post-manipulation measurement, after the vicarious dissonance procedure). This scale, translated from Stalder & Baron (1998), consists of 4 items: 
"The university should raise tuition yearly by a moderate amount" (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree), "How would you describe your overall attitude toward raising tuition?" (1 = extremely unfavorable, 7 = extremely favorable), "To what extent do you think there are advantages to never raising tuition?" (1 = no advantages, 7 = a great many; reverse scored), and "To what extent do you think that a modest yearly increase in tuition is a good general strategy in maintaining the quality of university education?" (1 = not at all, 7 = a great deal).

These pre- and post-manipulation intra-individual measures of behavioral intentions will allow us to measure and analyze the magnitude of change in behavioral intention, more specifically, the magnitude of reduction in dissonance (Martinie et al 2013).
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question3b:
We will measure the proximity with the group as a covariate (measured in the pre-manipulation questionnaire). Our measure of proximity with the group consists of 4 measures: group prototypicality, social identification with the group, similarity and interpersonal proximity to the group. 
1. The measure of prototypicality was based on the study by Hogg, Cooper-Shaw, & Holzworth (1993). Participants were asked to identify the characteristics of the group of youth (18 to 25 years of age) and to describe a prototype in no more five lines. They will then be asked to indicate how difficult it was for them to generate this description (1 = very easy, 7 = very difficult), how confident they were that this was an accurate description (1 = not very convinced, 7 = very convinced), and what percentage of the group they think generally agrees with their description. Finally, the prototypicality of the participants will be measured in 1 item: "How typical of the group of young people do you consider yourself to? "(1 = not at all representative, 7 = very representative), adapted in French from studies by Hogg, Cooper-Shaw, and Holzworth (1993). 
2. Social identification with the participant's group will be measured in 1 item, "I strongly identify with the youth group" (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree) (Reysen, Katzarska-Miller, Nesbit, & Pierce, 2013). 
3. The IOS scale (Aron, Aron, & Smollan, 1992) will measure interpersonal closeness to the group, and 
4. similarity to the group will be measured in 4 items, "How do you feel similar to the person in general", "...in terms of personal dispositions", "...in terms of attitudes", and "...in terms of background," (1 = not at all similar, 7 = very similar), adapted in French from the studies of Stephan, Liberman, & Trope (2011).
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question6c: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the Paired Samples T-Test and Repeated Measures ANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. The post-hoc Tukey-Kramer test adjusts for multiple comparisons.
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question7c:
As the questionnaires are filled out on computer, the participants are obliged to fill in the requested information in order to continue the experiment. 
Participants who have not completed the pre-manipulation questionnaire prior to the study will not be able to complete the experiment.
registration_responses.recommended-methods.procedure.question9b:
We will stop the experiment as soon as a participant asks for it. Moreover, we will provide participants with the opportunity to opt-out the study after completing the experiment.

A manipulation check will also be measured (see Procedure - post-manipulation questionnaire) to ensure that participants have been attentive to the procedure. Any participants who do not have a correct answer to this question will be excluded from the study.
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
To participate in this study, students will register on a platform. They will be given a brief presentation of the study, and will be asked to complete a pre-manipulation questionnaire online in order to participate in the study.

Pre-manipulation questionnaire. This questionnaire will include several measures: 
- Attitudes towards increasing tuition fees (Dependent Variable, Time 1)
- Proximity to the group (covariate)
- Demographic information (sex, date of birth, parents' socio-professional category, initials)

1. For the presence of vicarious dissonance condition: 
Participants will be greeted by an experimenter who will tell them that this is a paired study. The experimenter will then stage a telephone conversation with another experimenter during which he or she will learn that the other participant has arrived.

Once the participants are seated in the experiment room, the experimenter will tell them that this is a computer study. The experimenter will explain that he was studying linguistic subcultures, to explore whether the mere fact of living together might cause unique speech patterns to develop (Norton et al., 2003). We stressed these potential differences between groups to make group concerns salient (Turner et al., 1987). The experimenter will specify that in his research, he is particularly interested in the language differences between the youth group (18-25 years old) and the senior group (65-75 years old), and that the paired participant who performs the experiment at the same time as him is also part of the youth group. It will be indicated that this person is of the same sex as him/her: if it is a girl student, we will say that the pair is a girl, if it is a boy, we will say that the pair is a young man (control of group membership). The experimenter will then explain to the participants that in order to study these linguistic subcultures, one of the participants will have to write an argumentative text in favor of increasing tuition fees, while the other will judge this argumentative text on a set of linguistic criteria. To manipulate the negative consequences, the experimenter will explain that the Dean needed students to make speeches in favor of a tuition increase so that the Dean could use the arguments generated to justify any increase. To manipulate the choice of target and the target's opinion of the increasing tuition fees, participants will read a scripted exchange of e-mail messages (via Quaknet software) between the experimenter and the author of the advocacy text. The author of the argumentative text will express his total disagreement with the position to be defended and has asked the experimenter if he is obliged to write it. The experimenter will reply that, of course, he is not obliged to do so, but that he would really appreciate it if they wrote it. The author of the text will answer that he has no more questions and that he was ready to begin. Our cover will be corroborated by the presence of a sheet of paper and a pen on the table in each experimental room. Once instructions have been given, the experimenter will leave the experiment room and the participant will complete the tasks on the computer.
After reading a brief article on linguistic subcultures, all participants will be led to believe that the computer randomly assigns the position of judge or writer of the argumentative text. While waiting for their pair to write the argumentative text, the participants will complete the post-manipulation questionnaire. 

Post-manipulation questionnaire: 
- Attitudes towards increasing tuition fees (Dependent Variable, Time 2)
- Demographic information (sex, date of birth, parents' socio-professional category, initials)
- Manipulation check (perception of observed choice and the negative consequences follow from one’s actions, affiliation with the writer's group)

2. For the absence of vicarious dissonance condition:
Participants will complete only the post-manipulation questionnaire, with dependent measure (i.e., Attitudes towards increasing tuition fees in time 2), without following a vicarious dissonance procedure. 

We will use block randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the two equally sized, predetermined blocks 
For randomization, we will use https://www.random.org/integers/
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
Vicarious dissonance: It will be attributed the number “1” for participants in the condition "presence of dissonance", and the number “0” for participants in the condition "absence of dissonance".

Measurement of attitudes towards increasing tuition fees: Participants will indicate on a scale of 1 to 7 their attitudes towards increasing tuition fees, in time 1 and time 2. We will therefore obtain, for each participant, two measures of their attitudes towards increasing tuition fees, pre- and post-manipulation. 

Change in attitudes towards increasing tuition fees. The change in attitudes towards increasing tuition fees will result from the difference obtained between the measure of attitudes towards increasing tuition fees at time 1 and the measure of attitudes towards increasing tuition fees at time 2.

To measure the change in attitudes towards increasing tuition fees as a function of the presence or absence of vicarious dissonance, we will perform a repeated measures ANOVA with the measurement time (time 1 and time 2) as an intra-subject factor (repeated measures) and the vicarious dissonance (presence or absence) as an inter-subject factor.

IV1: Vicarious dissonance (presence versus absence), inter-subject factor. 

IV2: Measurement of attitudes towards increasing tuition fees (time 1 and time 2), intra-subject factor. 

DV: change in attitudes towards increasing tuition fees.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: Participants will be undergraduate student from Aix Marseille University, recruited through advertisements. Participants will be between 18 and 25 years old and will participate in study for experimental credit. Recruitment will take place from February 17 to March 31 at the most, until sufficient participants are recruited for the study.
We will post participant sign-up slots by week on the preceding Friday night, with 85 spots posted per week. We will post new slots each week if, on that Friday night, we are below 100 participants.

Our target sample size is 82 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 100, to provide for participant exclusions. An a-priori power analysis using G*Power 3.1.5 (Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner, & Lang, 2009) showed that 82 participants were necessary to detect a low effect size of .10 at the standard with an α-level of .05 and a power of .80
As soon as we get 82 reliable data.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-second.second.ques:
Vicarious dissonance: It will be attributed the number “1” for participants in the condition "presence of dissonance", and the number “0” for participants in the condition "absence of dissonance".

Measurement of attitudes towards increasing tuition fees: Participants will indicate on a scale of 1 to 7 their attitudes towards increasing tuition fees, in time 1 and time 2. We will therefore obtain, for each participant, two measures of their attitudes towards increasing tuition fees, pre- and post-manipulation. 

Proximity with the group: We will take the mean of the four questions (self-prototypicality, social identification at the group, similarity and interpersonal closeness with the group) to create a single measure of “proximity with the group”. We will therefore obtain, for each participant, a score of "proximity with the group" on a scale of 1 to 7. 

Change in attitudes towards increasing tuition fees. The change in attitudes towards increasing tuition fees will result from the difference obtained between the measure of attitudes towards increasing tuition fees at time 1 and the measure of attitudes towards increasing tuition fees at time 2.

To measure the change in attitudes towards increasing tuition fees as a function of the presence or absence of vicarious dissonance and as a function of proximity with the group of participant, we will perform a repeated measures ANOVA with the measurement time (time 1 and time 2) as an intra-subject factor (repeated measures), the vicarious dissonance (presence or absence) as an inter-subject factor, and proximity with the group as covariate.

IV1: Vicarious dissonance (presence versus absence), inter-subject factor. 

IV2: Measurement of attitudes towards increasing tuition fees (time 1 and time 2), intra-subject factor. 

Covariate: proximity with the group.

DV: change in attitudes towards increasing tuition fees.

Vicarious dissonance predicts that only observers highly identified with the group who observe the hypocritical behavior of another ingroup member will experience dissonance vicariously (Cooper & Hogg, 2007).
